flowent

Interface FlowentWhileLoop


  • public interface FlowentWhileLoop
    FlowentWhileLoop is an interface that can be utilized to create loops from within the method chain. More specifically, while loops. You can run a FlowentWhileLoop within the method chain by using Flowent.runWhileLoop.

    The iterate method is executed in the native while loop within the runWhileLoop method.

    Since:
    1.0.1
    See Also:
    Flowent.runWhileLoop(FlowentWhileLoop), FlowentWhileLoop

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Default Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean iterate(Flowent f, int iteration)
      This is the method called by the Flowent object within a for loop.
      default void onError(Flowent f, java.lang.Exception e, Protocol p)
      This is the FlowentWhileLoop's failsafe in case something goes wrong during execution of the iterate(Flowent, int) method.

    • Method Detail

      • iterate

        boolean iterate(Flowent f,
                int iteration)
         throws java.lang.Exception
        This is the method called by the Flowent object within a for loop.
        Parameters:
        f - The Flowent object that called this method
        iteration - The number of times before this call the method has been called
        Returns:
        True if the loop should be broken, false if it should continue
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - If something goes wrong, onError can pick up.
        Since:
        1.0.1
        See Also:
        Flowent.runWhileLoop(FlowentWhileLoop), onError(Flowent, Exception, Protocol), Flowent, FlowentWhileLoop

      • onError

        default void onError(Flowent f,
                     java.lang.Exception e,
                     Protocol p)
        This is the FlowentWhileLoop's failsafe in case something goes wrong during execution of the iterate(Flowent, int) method.

        If you try to call this object's execute method, and an exception is thrown, it is up to you to catch it. This is why the Flowent.runWhileLoop(FlowentWhileLoop) method is easier. It already has the try catch in it.

        By default, the onError method is set to print the exception's message and revive the thread, but you can override it very easily.

        Parameters:
        f - The Flowent object that called the method in the first place.
        e - The exception that caused the error.
        p - The protocol for denoting when the error happened. (while loop in this case)
        Since:
        1.0.1
        See Also:
        Flowent.runWhileLoop(FlowentWhileLoop), iterate(Flowent, int), Flowent, FlowentWhileLoop
